snippet: The burning of fossil fuels since the beginning of the industrial revolution is causing acidification, a change in the chemical balance that threatens the oceans’ web of life.
abstract: Editorial shudders at findings, published in the journal Science by paleoceanographers at Columbia University, showing that the burning of fossil fuels over the last several decades is producing more carbon dioxide than the world's oceans can safely absorb; notes that the result is rapid acidification in the oceans, a change in the chemical balance that threatens their web of life; laments that mankind has shown no signs of having the political will to slow, much less halt, the process.
lead_paragraph: The burning of fossil fuels since the beginning of the industrial revolution is causing acidification, a change in the chemical balance that threatens the oceans’ web of life.
